But, soft! What light through yonder window breaks? Yes, folks, it's new season time, and we're going to be wearing doublets. I'll talk you through the breeches next week. This season, I will mostly be channelling Mercurio, albeit with Michelle Obama's colour sense.

Joke! Had you for a minute there, didn't I? Don't worry. I might look as if I am wearing a doublet, but I am, in fact, wearing a sleeveless jacket, which is A Key Piece For This Season. Phew, huh? Just when you thought I might be looking a teeny bit ridiculous.

The sleeveless jacket was kind of inevitable, considering that, first, the motivation for retailers to present us with The Thing We Don't Have (and therefore need to buy) is stronger than ever in these crecrunched times. (Yes, crecrunched. That credit crunch phrase is so last season, don't you think? Needs a new season makeover, as we say in this neck of the woods.) The last couple of winters have done the groundwork, warming us up to the sleeveless concept (waistcoats, tank tops). Now, they hit us with the big ticket item.

Here's the strange part: sleeveless jackets could turn out to be a good thing. Not just in an anointed-by-Marc-Jacobs kind of a way (although they are) but in a surprisingly practical way. They are efficient in the business of keeping you warm and, unlike with the cape and cocoon styles with which stores will be trying to tempt you come October, you can still use your arms and even carry a bag.

If a padded doublet is too costumey for you, there are sleeveless blazers in store now: less catwalk warrior, more rock chick. You can even call these by the old-fashioned name of waistcoats, if you like. Forsooth, a gilet by any other name does look as sweet.

The Chelsea hotel, in New York. A hot day in summer. On the pavement outside, a grizzled blonde swills gin from a paper bag. In the lobby, a self-consciously hip young couple are having a domestic. At the front desk, a man with silvery hair stands with a pigeon on his shoulder. They are all regular guests.

The Chelsea, a landmark on Manhattan's West 23rd Street, has for decades been a mecca for bohemians - poets, painters and punks who lived and died in its rooms. Bob Dylan, Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin all once called it home. Edie Sedgwick set fire to it. Sid Vicious was charged with stabbing his girlfriend to death in room 100. In short, it's not what most people would call a great environment for families.

But try telling that to Joseph O'Neill, Sally Singer and their three children. O'Neill, an Irish writer whose new novel Netherland is hotly tipped to win this year's Man Booker prize, and Singer, a fashion journalist at Vogue, have set up an elegant, kitschy home in the hotel that describes itself as "a rest stop for rare individuals".

Saturday morning breakfast at the O'Neills' is a chaotic affair. When I visit, we sit over takeaway coffee and croissants in the tiny retro-chic kitchen as a flurry of small, screaming boys dash around us. The cat, Lola, a tawny, green-eyed queen with a powder-puff tail, swishes in and out of the room. O'Neill, dressed in cricket gear for his weekly game, is gracious and chatty.

"They like the Chelsea," he says, referring to the children, because despite the sensationalised stories, "There's a strong sense of community and it's one of the last fragments of a counter-cultural, unselfconscious place."

Singer enjoys the perverse glamour of living in a hotel. "I like that there are transients coming in every night," she says. "I love the continual stream of people to look at. I don't want to live in my own closed-off space. People just drop by and knock on your door. I want to open my door and let the world in - and let my kids out."

Their cosy, light-filled, three- bedroom suite, sparsely decorated with a mix of modern and antique pieces, seamlessly blends glamour and domesticity. In the living room, the white walls are filled with family photographs, while moody silkscreen images of Sid Vicious take pride of place above a curvy white sofa.

The children have their own brightly wallpapered two-room suite - one room for sleeping and the other for playing. Tucked away beyond the playroom, stretching along the entire length of the wall, cubby-hole shelves sparkle with a vast clutter of women's shoes. (O'Neill reveals that "Sally confessed only after we were together for a while that she was a fashion addict.")

The couple arrived in Manhattan in 1998, having emigrated from London with their two cats. "Sally was offered a job at Elle," says O'Neill, "so we crossed the ocean out of curiosity." He had no credit history and Singer, who is American, had virtually lost hers as a consequence of living abroad. So they ended up at the Chelsea with its bordello-like atmosphere, rock'n'roll ghosts and luminaries past and present. Since they have lived there, Deborah Harry, Ethan Hawke and the singer-songwriters Ryan Adams and Rufus Wainwright have taken up residence at various times.

Previously little known, O'Neill, 44, is this year's sensation for his novel Netherland. Hailed as the "King of New York" by New York Magazine, he's been compared to an array of literary greats from F Scott Fitzgerald to VS Naipaul. The New York Times Book Review praised Netherland as "the wittiest, angriest, most exacting and desolate work of fiction written about life in post 9/11 New York". Much of his racy thriller is set in the Chelsea itself. The narrator, Dutch exile Hans van der Broek, adrift after his wife leaves him, observes that at the Chelsea, "the furtiveness and ornamental diversity reminds him of the population of an aquarium he kept as a child".

For the O'Neill boys, too, the hotel is vivid and otherworldly, like the inside of a genie bottle, teeming with magical possibilities and exotic creatures. They race their bikes and skateboards along the white marble corridors past drag queens, mad old ladies, ageing rockers and men with angel wings and tiaras. For them, as their father says, every day is Halloween. Their mother thinks it's a good, stimulating environment for children.

"Come talk about why you live here," Singer asks her eight-year-old son, Malachy, as he shows his new comic book, one of a series that he wrote, coloured and stapled, scattered around the flat.

"Because I was born here," he snaps.

"What do you like about the hotel?" she persists.

"I like the guy who lived in the bathroom."

This gentleman, she explains, was "squatting in the communal bathroom. They had to kick him out one morning and he went crazy."

Does Malachy think any of the people are strange? "Mrs Bolow. The woman who lies in bed all day," he says after a while. "And the ghost who threw your platform shoe at me while I was sleeping." As for his younger brothers, they like living at the hotel "because you get to climb stuff".

What do their family and friends think about bringing up children in a hotel? "Most of our friends don't think it is strange," says O'Neill. "I'm not sure how my parents feel. I imagine the Chelsea is not what they had in mind, but that it's no big deal. It's not as if we're living in a yurt."

"I know there are many people who wouldn't dream of bringing up their children in a hotel, where a large proportion of the people are checking in for the night," adds Singer. "I know some people like to control the environment that children live in. They find comfort in predictability because the city is unexpected enough. But if you want to live in a sheltered world, where there's a doorman and no rogue element, you don't check into a hotel. What makes you persist, even when it doesn't make economic sense, is that people who live here deeply connect with it and don't think about things in a traditional way."

Singer considers the hotel to be an eclectic, multi-generational village. "There are grandparents whose grandchildren come and visit them and the teenagers next door, who we've known since they were kids, are our babysitters. There are other families in the building so the boys have friends here. They go to the local primary school and take part in the usual round of sleepovers, parties and adventures in the hallways. We also have eccentrics of every description and everyone tolerates it. There's that old-fashioned communal attitude here."

O'Neill claims he's not one for nostalgia but "the whole place is magic. But it's not a theme park. It's authentic, an organic village in the middle of the city, where the people are friendly and fascinating." It's also a place where you quickly learn to integrate the extraordinary into the everyday - the stream of fashion and film shoots and cocktail parties in the lobby. One of O'Neill's fondest memories is when he and Malachy, then a baby, were invited over for dinner by the late playwright Arnold Weinstein, who lived across the hall, and they ended up spending the evening with Arthur Miller, his photographer wife Inge Morath and friends. Their daughter, Rebecca Miller, the writer and filmmaker, was raised here for part of her childhood, in room 614, where Henri Cartier-Bresson sometimes read her bedtime stories and the Grateful Dead lived next door, smoking pot and having three-day-long parties with bus-loads of groupies.

When Singer, 43, was growing up in Oakland, California, in the 1970s, "with the surrealism of hippie culture, the violence of the Manson Family killings and the SLA [Symbionese Liberation Army] and Patty Hearst kidnapping happening in our backyard," she lost herself in fashion magazines. Seduced by the myths of Studio 54 and the Factory, she "wanted to work for Warhol's Interview magazine and wrote him letters. I love that whole world - the beat Generation, Allen Ginsberg, Gregory Corso. I was absorbed by the fabulousness of it," she says. "So it was inevitable that this is where I should live."

"Actually, it was my idea to come to the Chelsea," O'Neill says, throwing his wife a knowing glance. "Sally made it happen. I had the outsider's sense of possibility."

O'Neill met Singer in 1991 when she was his editor at the publisher Farrar, Straus and Giroux on his first book, This Is the Life, shortly after graduating in law from Cambridge. They lived in Stockwell, south London, and upgraded to Soho while he worked as a barrister, mainly defending death-row prisoners in the Commonwealth. She worked for the London Review of Books and later British Vogue. Moving to New York, they expected to stay briefly and rented a seventh-floor, one-bedroom apartment in the Chelsea, shifting to a bigger place upstairs when Malachy was born in 1999.

After two more sons followed - Pascal, now seven, and Oscar, five - they left the hotel. "You know, some people leave because of the mice, some because of the cockroaches and others because of the people in the elevator," says O'Neill. "For us, it was sheer practicality. We thought our life had to assume a more adult size." So they bought "an adult-size, eight-bedroom Victorian" in Flatbush, one of the not-so-fashionable parts of Brooklyn, and spent months renovating it.

O'Neill "liked the light, the summer roses, the horse chestnuts" and melting-pot neighbourhood. The boys and the cat enjoyed "having a garden, lots of stairs and rooms to run and hide in. They loved the ice-cream truck that went down the street." But Singer was miserable and felt isolated from her Manhattan friends.

"I thought I was living the life that my parents hoped for," she says. "but when I showed them the house they were disappointed. They're so used to coming to see me in seedy neighbourhoods with two rooms and a bed that pulls out of the wall. I know many English people think children need gardens, country houses to escape to. I don't want that. I think there's too much stuff in the world. You're not light on your feet and can't go at any moment."

Within months, Singer was desperate to return. O'Neill reluctantly agreed. "Well, you know," he sighs good-naturedly, "if your wife says to you, 'I don't want to live here any more,' what are the options?" After 18 months, they sold the house and returned to their old flat, knocking together an adjacent studio to create a three-bedroom apartment, for which they pay $5,000 (£2,600) a month in rent.

"It surprised me how attached I am to the Chelsea," says Singer. I cried for days when we left. It's a village that I feel at home in. The residents feel they live in a sprawling extended house. We often have dinner with our neighbours. Last Thanksgiving, she "made a feast for 30. We cooked here and moved upstairs to my friend Susan's for dinner. Then we went up to Gerald's top-floor apartment, which has a roof garden, for drinks."

Some thrive on the buzz of communal living. Others come here to disappear. O'Neill and Singer are drawn by the diversity of the Chelsea hotel, which is like New York itself - dark, crumbling and colourful - a microcosm of Manhattan, where everyone has a story.

"These days, to rent and not buy is a radical act. We chose to rent this place instead of buying an apartment elsewhere and we don't have anything to show for it. A lot of people find that unacceptable," says O'Neill.

But don't they love their life here? "Yeah, exactly," he beams. "How do you place a value on happiness? You'll never have a conversation about real estate in this hotel. And that's because the owner, Stanley Bard, has created this extraordinary community that reflects his whimsies and his peculiar, rather crazed priorities."

They speak of Bard with warmth and frustration. He was ousted by his two partners last year after running the hotel for 50 years, helping many brilliant artists along the way. The change in management, stream of evictions and public disputes have left many residents worried that the Chelsea will be turned into just another boutique hotel. "It's a fake war," O'Neill says philosophically. "We just have to ride it out."

In a world where imitation is celebrated, the Chelsea is a bulwark against conformity. As Arthur Miller wrote, "This hotel does not belong to America. There are no vacuum cleaners, no rules and no shame."

"It's a grounding place and it defines my existence in New York," says Singer. She describes how Hiroya, a Japanese artist who paid his way through life with his paintings, left several works of art to the hotel before dying of a heroin overdose a few years ago. One of his paintings, which hangs between the seventh and eighth floors, has writing scrawled across it that translates as: "From here, it's heaven." "That's how we feel," she adds. "I can't imagine living anywhere else."

Wednesday June 4: The Clifton pub, St John's Wood, London

I find Rhys Ifans and Dafydd "Daf" Ieuan hiding behind their sunglasses in a London pub's beer garden, working their way through some bottles of cider. Would Ifans like some crisps or anything? "Oh no," he replies quickly. "No, no. No solids." The Welsh pair - not shy about their enjoyment of drink or drugs - are here to talk about the band they've formed with eight sometime musicians, mostly from Cardiff. They are called The Peth, which means "thing" in Welsh. It is also in-band slang for cocaine.

Ieuan's normal source of employment is as the drummer in Super Furry Animals. Ifans is an actor, the scruffily charismatic star of Notting Hill and Enduring Love. They're a bit fuzzy on exactly how long they've known each other, but they think it's around 25 years, their friendship dating back to a Cardiff flat-share in the very early days of the Super Furry Animals, and a good few years before Ifans made his big-screen debut in 1997's Twin Town, a film routinely described as "the Welsh Trainspotting".

"I was kind of homeless at the time," says Ifans, "so Daf offered that I sleep in his studio." Briefly, Ifans sang with an embryonic incarnation of the Super Furries, and they attempted to record some demos. "But we passed out, didn't we?" recalls Ieuan. "And we had to stop recording."

Ieuan went on to make eight studio albums with the Welsh indie-psychedelic band; Ifans has just finished shooting the latest film from Richard Curtis, The Boat That Rocked, about British pirate radio. After The Peth's autumn tour he's playing the title role in an adaptation of Welsh drug-smuggler Howard Marks's bestselling autobiography Mr Nice. "There's gonna be a lot of dope smoking," the actor says with a grin. "That's gonna stretch me!"

But, through the years, their friendship remained firm. When Ieuan began writing songs for an album, a collection called The Golden Mile that hymns the praises of a stretch of Cardiff road where you can buy all your store-cupboard staples ("Food, beer, plectrums, strings, drugs, whatever"), he decided to ask Ifans if he'd like to sing them. Who better to front a set of beery but tuneful songs that evoke the best bits of Oasis, Happy Mondays and the Super Furries than the man commonly referred to as "Britain's most rock'n'roll actor"? The album's lead single says it all. It's called Let's Go Fucking Mental.

Which brings us to the other reason Ifans is hiding out at the back of a quiet pub this afternoon. The off-duty behaviour - boozing, partying, gobbing at the paparazzi - of this fully paid-up member of the Primrose Hill set often propels him into the pages of the tabloids. But Ifans' value to the red-tops has rocketed since he began going out with Sienna Miller in mid-2007. And since they split up, it's zoomed higher still. With unfortunate timing, the news that Miller, 26, reportedly dumped Ifans, 40, by telephone has appeared in The Sun this very morning. She, it is said, caught him going through her texts; he, apparently, was suspicious of her friendship with Matthew Rhys, her co-star in The Edge Of Love; she, allegedly, couldn't cope with his jealousy.

Mucky and deeply personal stuff for sure, and it goes some way to explaining Ifans' wobbly demeanour and slurred diction, if not the fact that he's turned up to the interview without any shoes.

Wednesday July 2: Portmeirion Town Hall, Portmeirion, Wales

We are in Sir Clough Williams-Ellis's model village. The Peth are playing their first-ever gig in the town hall, the opening leg of a five-date tour of the Welsh hinterlands. In the foyer the merchandise stall is selling T-shirts that say "Pwy Ffwc Di'r Peth?" ("Who The Fuck Are The Peth?").

Underneath a vaulted 17th-century ceiling depicting the labours of Hercules, the band pile through their 50-minute set. Ifan clutches a can of Fosters and hangs on to the microphone stand for dear life. Behind the singers, Ieuan plays a Fender Telecaster; it's the first time he's played guitar in public. He, like Ifans, is wearing shades. A couple of the musicians he's recruited appear to be playing little more than their knees. For Last Man Standing, The Peth are joined by an eleventh musician, on banjo. They sing Let's Go Fucking Mental, which they describe as a "beer chucker" anthem, with Ifans screaming the word "mental!" 27 times as the song clatters to a halt. All told, it should be a disaster. In fact, it's brilliant. Like the Happy Mondays, the band have a shambolic magnetism, the sheer strength of their tunes providing a centre of gravity in all the chaos.

In the pub in London I had asked Ifans about the lyrics to Last Man Standing, which, melody-wise, is a breezy pop song: "If I only had my crack pipe it just might have kept me sane", it begins, "instead of picking up the toaster and toasting half my brain." Can he remember how those lyrics came up?

"Uh, I can, yeah..." begins Ifans. "It was during the time when I was hanging out with Pete Doh..." He stops and scratches his Worzel Gummidge hair. "It was... It came..."

Was it inspired by the environment you were in at the time?

"No, it was inspired by the cult..." He tails off again.

The cult of Pete Doherty?

"No, the cult, the culture of that time... That whole obsession with... The crack pipe has never kept anyone sane. There's a lot of stuff in there that is very raw, lyrically. And there's a lot of stuff that is just complete and utter situationist mischief."

What category does that line fall into?

"Em..." Ifans pauses. "Mischief," he says finally, twice. "We had this debate when we were writing lyrics: are we swearing too much? Not because we think swearing is wrong, but is it lazy?" In the end, The Peth's attitude to lyrics can be summed up as "Oh, just keep it in. We're not Radiohead," says Ifans with his lazy, vulpine smile. "We're not poets."

The day after Portmeirion, The Peth hit the small town of Bala. And Bala hits them back: Rhys Ifans gets in a fight with a local chip-shop owner, while two other members of the band are visited in their hotel room by the local constabulary. There is, as Ifans later describes it, "claret all over the room." The police tell The Peth to "have some breakfast, have a drink, and get out of town."

Thursday July 10: Blossom Street Studios and Hoxton Square Bar & Kitchen, Shoreditch, London

The Peth straggle into a studio for the Weekend photoshoot. Rhys Ifans is wearing many of the same clothes he had on the previous week. But his T-shirt is new. With evident pride he says that a couple of fans made it for him. "Ccadw Dy Fw*in Fish" ("Stuff Your Fucking Fish"), it says, which is what - according to the papers - "jilted star" Ifans shouted at the Bala chip-shop owner.

Nine-tenths of The Peth are wearing sunglasses. The only one who isn't is the one who's not actually in the band; he's a mate, and he's pretending to be the drummer, who's gone awol.

"It's the first time I've been on stage as me," reflects Ifans, of the Welsh shows. "And this may sound such a naff thing, but in the initial daze of nervousness, because I didn't have a character, the sunglasses became so important. I did two gigs in girls' pink sunglasses. I've got to wean myself off the shades."

Everyone drinks Kronenbourg, which has been hastily fetched by a studio assistant. Someone is rolling a joint. The attention span of this dirty near-dozen is not lengthy. A lone voice suggests they all stand in a long line for the photographer "and someone will snort you".

"I'll do that!" bellows Ifans.

The video for Let's Go Fucking Mental is being made by artists Jake and Dinos Chapman. "I was hoping they'd just give me a mannequin with a cock coming out its head... We do share a very similar sense of humour," says Ifans.

They first met when all three were hired by Italian fashion label Missoni. "They do horrible clothes, but they wanted non-model models and they flew us out to Milan and said you can have some free clobber. Well, I'll go anywhere for free clobber. So it was me, Jake and Dinos and some other people I didn't know, and we had to do a catwalk show. We could barely walk in a straight line.

"So they're old friends," he continues. "And I'm a fan of their work. But they wouldn't have offered to do this if they didn't like the music. They're very particular people."

In fact, the Peth video commission - the first the brothers have accepted - is something of a favour returned. The Chapmans are currently making their own quasi-autobiographical film, featuring Ifans as their dad and Samantha Morton as their mum (next year, Ifans will also star in the brothers' first "proper" film, as an art critic). In return, Ifans asked if the Chapmans would make The Peth's music video.

Ifans pulls up a still from the Chapmans' biopic on his mobile phone. It shows him and Morton standing beneath a giant model of a vaginal passage.

Ifans says: "It's the first time in my life where I'm not the biggest cunt in the room."

Photoshoot quickly over, the band straggle out for the short walk to the Hoxton Square Bar & Kitchen, venue for tonight's London debut. Their guest list numbers 260. "Yeah," sniffs Ifans, "if you want to rob Primrose Hill, tonight's the night."

Sure enough, when The Peth take to the stage in the tiny sweat box, the audience includes Kate Moss and Sadie Frost dancing at the front, while The Charlatans' Tim Burgess and former Libertine Carl Barât linger near the back.

As in Portmeirion, the gig teeters on the edge of sozzled chaos: on Let's Go Fucking Mental, Ifans manages to scream "mental!" only 17 times, while on bluesy ballad Stonefinger he seems to lose the plot entirely.

Monday July 28: Final Cut edit suite and Soho House, Soho, London

Is Stonefinger about you-know-who? The opening lines are: "Every little thing you said would break me, all of it came true / Every bit of love I give, you mock it, yes you do..."

Thus far, I've been loth to mention Sienna Miller. In Portmeirion, a journalist from music magazine Q asked Ifans about his ex; Ifans responded by walking out. But at our first meeting, in the pub, when I suggested that Ifans sounds completely broken when he sings Stonefinger, he replied: "I was, I was in a bad way... Heartbroken. It's a diary, in a way, this album. Coz I've been through several states of mind through the process..."

The Golden Mile has taken the best part of two years to make, with studio sessions in Cardiff fitted around other commitments. On the day they recorded Stonefinger, Ifans "fell off the train, fell into the room, Daf stuck a mic in my face, I thought it was a fucking ice-cream, I was that off me head."

Since Stonefinger's public unveiling in Portmeirion, The Sun - alongside splashes about Miller and her supposed new beau Balthazar Getty - have been reporting that the song is about Miller.

Ieuan says that he wrote half the album's lyrics on his own, but Ifans wrote some bits and bobs, including Stonefinger. While Ifans is off on the phone I ask Ieuan which lines are about Miller. "None whatsoever," he replies emphatically. When Ifans returns, I ask him to tell me about Stonefinger.

"I'd split up with me girlfriend. No, no, not the little one," he says, meaning Miller, adding that the lyrics are approximately 18 months old. So are any of the album's lyrics about... "No, no, fuck no," he interjects. "Jesus Christ, no. She doesn't deserve a fucking song, that one."

It's lunchtime, and we're on the roof terrace of Soho House. Ifans was unsure if we'd get in; he thought he might still be banned from the private members' club after an "incident" involving a "small fire". But Jake Chapman has smoothed our passage.

We had met at an edit suite earlier in the day to see a rough-cut of the Chapmans' video. There had been no sign of Ifans - Ieuan had last seen him at four that morning, going off with "some bird". He finally rolls in nearly an hour late, full of apologies and with the address of the edit suite written on a pink, heart-shaped Post-it note pinned to his chest. His underpants are poking out of his back pocket.

The current public view of Ifans, as filtered through the papers, is of a brokenhearted, unhinged man partying his way through a break-up, his bonkers band a convenient excuse for rock'n'roll excess.

"Absolutely," he says, the band has been a refuge during his recent troubles. "It all had a kind of poetic symmetry. I'm not the kind to lie down on a couch... This band was bang on the right time." His impulse was to think, "right, I'm going back to gang life."

But for all the shambling mess that seems to attend him, like the dustcloud hovering above Peanuts' Pig-Pen, Ifans is serious about The Peth, and serious about it not being seen as a dilettantish excursion by a bored thespian. "This is a proper band," he and Ieuan chorus. No one wants Ifans's celebrity status to get in the way - even though it inevitably does.

At Soho House The Peth drink cider and Ifans waves his underpants about. Chapman goes off home, motorbike helmet in hand; unbeknown to him, Ifans has secreted his pants inside.

In a short while, Chapman returns, and it's on to the pub, followed by Soho House again. And it's only six o'clock in the evening. I leave soon afterwards, waking up on a bus, some distance past my house, without my bag containing my laptop, iPod, house keys, sunglasses. The next day I make frantic phone calls to the rest of our party, trying to retrieve it. Apparently, most headed home in the early evening but Ifans and Chapman kept going. We know this because Ifans is in the next day's papers, careering out of nightclub Bungalow 8 at 3.30am, straight into another fight with photographers. The stories report that he spent the evening with Rod Stewart's daughter Kimberly - another attempt, they suggest, to "bounce back from his split from Sienna Miller."

Then Ifans disappears. For two days. No one can reach him - except the long arm of the tabloid lens. They photograph him and Stewart leaving her house and having "nosh in a seedy Soho strip club".

Many phone calls later, I finally receive word that Ifans has my bag. Remarkably, everything is there. Except my sunglasses. I text Jake Chapman to thank him for all his efforts in trying to locate Ifans and my bag. Shame about the glasses, I say, but in the circumstances, it's not surprising they've been lost.

Chapman texts back. "Think you'll find your glasses on the front page of most tabloids..."

I look online. Sure enough, there on The Sun's Bizarre pages is Rhys Ifans, strolling with his latest flame, wearing my sunglasses. At the time of writing, he still hadn't returned them. Not weaned off the sunglasses yet, then.

I would have thought my mobile phone bills come a pretty long way down the list of environmental threats facing the Earth. Still, every little helps and maybe it would have been green to stop getting paper bills. That, after all, was the reason Virgin Mobile, part of the Richard Branson conglomerate, gave customers when it recently introduced a £1 per month charge to those who would not agree to receive their bills electronically.

I must admit the teeniest bit of scepticism about Branson's commitment to saving the environment. Paper bills are not quite up there with running a long-distance airline - never mind competing to get into outer space - when it comes to causing global warming. Virgin Mobile's idea of sponsorship doesn't involve the usual "green" things like woods, rivers or small wild animals, but it does sponsor the Big Brother television programme.

I have no objection to having phone bills emailed to me, but Virgin has not exactly developed a user-friendly method of receiving them. The procedure is so time-consuming that by the time I have completed it, the saving of £1 means I am probably "working" at less than the minimum wage rate.

I was also a little perturbed that this commendable attempt to reduce paper waste was being taken by one of the main purveyors of junk mail to our home.

Scarcely a week goes by without some missive trying to persuade us to fly more on Branson's airline or change to his broadband company. I emailed Virgin Mobile's managing director, Graham Oxby, saying I would agree to his proposed change of terms, if Virgin would agree to allow me to make a deduction from my bill for each piece of junk mail sent to our house.

I was phoned a few days later by a very polite chap called James who told me Virgin Mobile could not stop other Virgin companies sending their mailings. He did not really engage with my point that as most of the companies have the same chairman or president it would be remarkably easy to give an instruction to all of them to stop junk mailing anybody.

All James could do was stop Virgin Mobile, and its apparently related broadband company, junk mailing me. Even those companies would not stop sending their letters to my wife unless she personally asked them to stop it. It would appear she, like most of the population have, in Virgin's eyes, a divine right to receive junk mail.

Virgin and I are in something of a legal grey area: I have not agreed to pay the £1 charge, though that has not stopped it helping itself to the sum through my direct debit. It has not agreed to pay my charges. The best analysis is probably that the contract continues on the original terms with neither Virgin nor me being entitled to charge in respect of mailings.

As corporate misbehaviour goes this is relatively mild stuff. No real harm to anyone is done by the £1 charge and its junk mail is no more than a minor irritant to those who receive it.

For blatant hypocrisy, though, it has few rivals. A few dozen more customers refusing to pay the charge would probably make it unworkable and inflict upon Virgin the chaos some might think such a display of double standards deserves.

· Richard Colbey is a barrister

Which country has the best diplomats?

Life as a diplomat is not all Ferrero-Rocher chocolates and cocktail parties, and it will take more than smooth talking to clear up the mess after the war over South Ossetia. But was David Miliband, the foreign secretary, right to call this a crisis which needs "British values and British diplomacy"? The UK is on the hawkish side of the EU debate, blaming Moscow for "blatant aggression", though it did urge Georgia to act with restraint in the face of Russian provocation.

Britain still punches above its weight as one of the five permanent members of the UN security council. It has a veto, but few chances to use it. The fact that Russia (and China) also sit at the world's "top table" limits the scope for coercive diplomacy, especially as the punitive measures being mooted would hurt others more than Russia.

The Foreign Office used to be seen as the Rolls-Royce of diplomatic services and did not take kindly to the suggestion a decade ago that it be replaced by a fax machine. Still, important diplomatic business is now conducted directly between capitals rather than embassies, or via presidential prime ministers like Tony Blair. The FO was perceived as having appeased the Serbs during the Balkan wars of the early 1990s. The fiasco of Iraq and its non-existent WMD did not cover it in glory either.

French diplomacy can be steely, and it was the flamboyant Nicolas Sarkozy who flew to Moscow to secure the Georgia ceasefire. Germany is well-connected in the Caucasus and appreciated in the Arab world. The EU has not yet got its own diplomats though its Spanish foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, has taken the lead in dealing with Iran's nuclear ambitions. Turkey has proved a useful mediator between Israel and Syria. Could this crisis be the hour of the Nordics? Sweden's foreign minister, Carl Bildt, flew to Tiblisi on behalf of the Council of Europe. His Finnish colleague, Alexander Stubb, representing the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, is a former EU policy wonk who makes even the famously brainy Miliband look dim by comparison.
Ian Black

Why is sterling falling against the dollar?

If you are thinking about jetting to New York for a cheap shopping spree courtesy of the strong pound, you've left it too late. Sterling has completed its 11th straight daily fall against the US currency - something that has not happened for 37 years. It has fallen from a peak of just over $2.10 last year to about $1.85 in London yesterday and looks likely to fall further.

Three big factors lie behind the pound's weakness. The first is that the dollar has been getting stronger because foreign exchange dealers believe the Federal Reserve will soon raise interest rates to combat inflation. Higher rates attract flows of investment into a currency, thus pushing up its value.

The second is a growing belief in the markets that the Bank of England will be forced to cut the cost of borrowing in the UK in response to the threat of recession. When the Bank said on Wednesday that it saw inflation falling sharply next year and growth grinding to a halt, sterling dropped by 3 cents against the dollar. The gap between interest rates in the UK and the US is wide - 5% compared with 2% - but dealers expect it to narrow. That said, the downward trend in the value of sterling started well before the Bank released its inflation report, suggesting that the markets are looking at the UK and not liking what they see.

Over the past 10 years, the UK has run ever-bigger trade deficits, financed by the speculative flows of capital that came flooding into London when global markets were booming. The credit crunch has meant those flows have dried up and the markets have realised that the UK's trade deficit is unsustainable. This looks like reality checkpoint.
Larry Elliott

Should we listen to thinktanks?

The short answer is yes, with serious provisos. Thinktanks are the public equivalent of the chattering classes. They provide excellent debating points at dinner parties. They raise controversial issues of the day. They can influence people, particularly the "movers and shakers" who make political decisions. They are usually staffed by bright, young things who enjoy putting over controversial views. The people who staff thinktanks tend to go on to stand as MPs, become directors of companies or charities or advise people in government.

The serious proviso is to make sure you don't take their views as gospel. They often come from a particular political perspective - authoritarian or libertarian - right of centre or left of centre. So the type of report they commission aims to promote that point of view. The Adam Smith Institute - well on the libertarian right - would never commission a report on, say, nationalising utilities or turning the railways into non-profit making organisations. Yet the left of centre Fabian Society has published a study proposing that Scotrail become a not-for-profit company.

There is a pecking order in thinktanks, too, and some are more influential than others. The Adam Smith Institute and the Centre for Policy Studies had their heyday in setting the Thatcherite agenda. Demos and the Institute for Public Policy Research were at their zenith influencing Tony Blair's agenda. And the centre-right Policy Exchange is one of the main drivers for influencing David Cameron's Tories.

So the controversy over its latest report on the failure of the regeneration of Northern cities, written by a Liberal Democrat adviser and denounced as "barmy" by Cameron, is an exception to the rule - though it is firmly in the centre right's domain by querying whether too much public money has been spent.

There is one other point about thinktanks - to be really effective they should have a limited shelf life. One senior Tory told me they usually run out of steam after 20 years.
David Hencke

The very term gap year is a misnomer; it implies a space to be filled, something passively waiting rather than a period when a young adult will be actively constructing an identity and taking responsibility for their own lives in a way unlikely to be matched by friends going straight to university or college. Parents might, if you are lucky, top up your funding, but they won't be there to get you out of sticky situations.

If you travel with friends, is that just going to be the sixth form in a tropical environment? Do you have to leave the UK? Answer these questions and see if you can work out the kind of gap experience that will most benefit you.

The gap year isn't for everyone; there is no moral advantage to doing one or to not doing one - it is your choice. What a gap experience will do, though, is change you; your outlook, your attitudes, your plans will all be informed by the experiences you have had and things you have seen. You will have had to develop personal responsibility and independence. Travelling may even get to be a habit; if your first port of call when you arrive at university is the office of the Erasmus/Socrates or study abroad coordinator, you'll know you caught something really infectious while you were away.

· Dr Jane Prince is principal lecturer in the psychology department at the University of Glamorgan

How did you score?

Mostly a)s

You are the person of whom everyone thinks when they think of gap years. You are someone who values spontaneity and embraces the unknown. Your gap year will just happen; the round-the-world ticket with no pre-planned stops is purchased and you are ready to go. If a single place appeals to you, then you could stay there for the whole year - or just wander to a different place every week. Who knows. You need to explore what you want to get out of your gap year, to go with all the photos and memories. Don't search for the exciting just for the sake of stimulation; life is sometimes calm and mundane and yet still enjoyable.

Mostly b)s

You like to plan ahead, so you would probably be attracted to a structured experience such as those provided by commercial companies. These can be expensive and some feel a bit "packaged". You could try to find local charities that take volunteers if they have certain skills, and then apply yourself to acquiring those skills. Or apply to one of the UN projects where young people from two countries spend several months working together on a local community project. But give yourself time for a bit of spontaneity, too - it will give you confidence in your ability to deal with uncertainties. And life is filled with these.

Mostly c)s

You would like your gap year to relate to your career plans. You might be planning actual employment relating to your anticipated career. Try to think outside the box, too, and look for transferable skills; these might be organisational (getting visas and tickets coordinated takes some skill), communication (persuading that office manager in Ulan Bator to give you a job) or even practical. Take the opportunity to learn a new language and you will demonstrate to a future employer not just a useful skill but also your capacity for tenacity and hard work.

Mostly d)s

You are the kind of person who sees no great benefit in being a long way from home; you enjoy finding out more about your own community. Talk of a gap year tends to invoke an image of far-flung and exotic places, so your initial thoughts might be that a gap year isn't for you. Why not consider spending some time working and travelling in one of the most beautiful islands in the world? There are opportunities to work in a range of paid occupations (including community projects) and get to meet other international travellers. And at the end of a gap year in Britain, you could even reward yourself with a couple of weeks' holiday on a sunny beach somewhere.

Ribena was the superior fruit drink of my youth, and over the years I've consumed a fair amount of blackcurrants in liquid form, though more as cassis in kir and the like. I've even tried to make cassis with blackcurrants from the solitary bush in my garden, but it wasn't a success. But until meeting Edward Thompson, engineer, fruit farmer and guiding force of Pixley Berries, I'd never given much thought to cordial production or growing blackcurrants on a large scale.

And here they were, row upon row of them, different varieties with different qualities, with names such as Ben Hope, Ben Tirran, Ben Gairn and Pixley Black, 300 acres of them in all. There were raspberries and apples, too, but the blackcurrants are the backbone of this business.

"Ribena is God," Thompson said. He's a tall man, with unruly, white hair, a ruddy face and an insistent enthusiasm for his products. "It's easy to criticise them, but they've put a lot of money into research and development. And we supply them with a lot of blackcurrants. But Ribena is a clear cordial, which means it's been refined to take out the natural cloudiness of the juice. And the more you refine something, the more you take out the flavour. And I'm preoccupied by flavours. Pixley Berries cordial is cloudy, and I'd say it packs more flavour."

Thompson is especially fond of the Pixley Black, which he selected after a worldwide search, having become concerned about the effect that global warming was having on the seasons (less winter chill, more summer heat). This, he felt, is a superior blackcurrant - superior in flavour, that is, not in productivity. "Here," he said, stripping off a handful of plump berries, "try them."

They burst easily in my mouth, and sent the sweet/sour juice gushing down my throat. The flavour was as full and rich as the fruit looked. "See?" Thompson said.

The thing about blackcurrants, it seems, is not only do different varieties taste different - "The question is, do they taste good?" Thompson said - but they have different ripening times, because they have different time clocks and respond differently to different temperatures, which differ according to which field they grow in, because fields have different microclimates. "Vive la différence," Thompson said.

No, his currants aren't organic. For all its robust flavour, the blackcurrant is a delicate shrub, prone to spider mite, leaf spot and aphids, but they'd cut down pesticides and built a cordon sanitaire of hedgerow and grass around each field to promote bird life and insects that feed on insects that would otherwise infest the crop.

Then, from July to August, pickers strip the fruit from the bushes, using machinery that Thompson adapted for the purpose - in a former incarnation, he had an engineering business. The pickers, as seems customary these days, come from eastern Europe, in some cases two or more generations of them. (It makes you wonder what will become of British agriculture, not to mention our restaurants, hotels and hospitals, when the xenophobia promoted by a sad alliance of cheap politicians and cheaper newspapers reduces the flow of itinerant labour on which we rely to do the jobs we are too lazy or too snooty to do ourselves. But that is by the by.)

Then it's off to the juicing plant, all gleaming stainless steel and the heady smell of fruit. Even here, the fruit is treated with kid gloves, allowing time for maceration and natural filtration, so that the cordials retain the oomph of the natural fruit, ready for bottling as pure blackcurrant cordial, or mixed with juice from the farm's Cox's apples or elderflower or Scottish raspberry juice. Or champagne, cider, white wine or gin, come to that. ("We do try to be different," Thompson said. "We have to.") Or poured over ice cream. Or... well, I'm sure you get the picture.

Anyone looking to this column for help in resolving the age-old struggle for supremacy between nurture and nature (and it's hardly for me to second-guess the readers' motivation) is in for a brutal disappointment.

Today's restaurant is Quo Vadis, which stands in the heart of London's dismally sanitised Soho, as it has done for some 80 years. Previously the upstairs bit was Karl Marx's workplace, and these rooms' present incarnation as a private members' club for moneyed media types, vaguely on the lines of the one a few doors up opened by Karl's cousin Groucho, is an irony that needn't detain us today.

What need detain us is that in the 1990s Quo Vadis was taken over by a syndicate including my old schoolmate Matthew Freud. Matthew, as you know, is frequently cited by those on the nurture side of the debate as the single most compelling argument against the power of heredity. Times beyond counting I've challenged Steve Jones, Richard Dawkins and other top-ranked geneticists to explain the progression, in just three generations, from Sigmund to Matthew via Clement, and never have they dared take up the gauntlet.

One up to upbringing over environment there, then. The equaliser, however, comes from the latest owners of Quo Vadis, Sam and Eddie Hart. These brothers are the sons of gifted restaurateurs themselves, their parents owning Hambleton Hall, a country house hotel and restaurant in Rutland about which people have long raved.

Now this might tempt some to chalk up another to nurture, on the obvious grounds that growing up in that world inevitably imbued the boys with their parents' abilities. I won't have it. The outstanding restaurateur is too rare a creature to be explained by environmental influences. The gift is as much bred in the bone as one for football, and these Harts are the Charlton brothers of the food world. It's true that they have yet to fall out for opaque reasons connected with their mother Cissie, but in any British squad for the Restaurateur World Cup a place would have to be found for both because they bring to their work flair, passion, perfectionism and the surest of touches.

At Quo Vadis, their first major non-Hispanic venture after opening the admired Spanish restaurant Fino and the even more vaunted tapas joint Barrafina, both stalked the room, eyes slaking from side to side in the quest for problems in the manner of the masters of the trade Chris Corbin and Jeremy King (The Wolseley). Eventually they settled down for a late afternoon digestif with my so-called rival Giles Coren, who was taking a well-merited break from composing his much-loved lyrical odes to the subeditors of the Times, but if they'd hunted down and resolved any failings during their travels around the parquet floor, they certainly weren't at our table. In fact the entire experience, from the warm and jolly greeting onwards, was pretty much perfect.

Whether through good sense or parsimony, they have left this spacious Edwardian room - antique frosted-glass mirrors, low ceilings providing unusually good acoustic - largely untouched, save for some squishy, tan-coloured banquettes and the abstracts on the walls. They have also gone for the sort of unponcey, emulsion-free, old-fashioned British menu that not only goes with the room but makes the heart sing at the sight of at least a dozen dishes you want to eat.

My friend kicked off with whitebait, and a finer, more accurately fried serving of that delectable little fish (served with impeccable tartare sauce) he could not remember. I went for the razor clams, those underrated princelings of the seafood world, and these were also superb, arriving enticingly browned in their shells and laced with garlic and parsley.

The main courses were better still, thanks to the obvious-sounding but highly unusual synthesis of beautiful meat and accurate cooking. "I must tell you, this is the lightest, tenderest lamb I've ever eaten," enthused my friend of his beautifully pink and milky roast saddle, served in one gratifyingly vast circular slab. I felt the same about a veal cutlet of a meltiness and richness of flavour I couldn't recall. Vegetables were also flawless, the spinach drawing an almost mystified, "But everything is brilliant here" from my friend's roseate lips (the pinot grigio turned out to be pink, and delicious with it).

Raspberry trifle was slightly too sweet for my embittered palate, but he loved it, and it was worth the money just for the aesthetics. Even the cover charge I alighted on in the quest for a quibble turned out to cover terrific bread and olives and filtered water, which seemed a fair deal for two quid.

No, there's nothing for it but to accept this is one of those ultra-rare, spirit-lifting restaurants that has you proselytising its splendours to anyone polite enough to listen. But then these Hart boys do have their forebears' talent stamped throughout their DNA. If only the same could be said for Matthew Freud and that Pedigree Chum-peddling sire of his.

We have lived in a house with a garden for some time but have no experience of making compost. My youngest, aged eight, has been composting at school and is very interested, so we thought we should try it at home. My son wants a wormery, which, frankly, scares me. Is that the same as a compost bin? What are our options? We are a family of five, with three boys aged from eight to 13. Our garden is 100ft by 60ft, mostly consisting of neglected plants and lawn. Most of our waste is household scraps - what is suitable for compost?
Kelly Salter, Bath

The first thing to do is look at the Recycle Now website (recyclenow.com). If you go to the home composting section and put in your postcode, it tells you which compost bins your council offers at a reduced rate (note: you may still be able to buy these cheaper at garden centres, so shop around). Plus there's a very good section on what to put in your compost bin and what to leave out. You can also buy wormeries and bokashi systems (more on those later) online but the choice is more limited.

A wormery isn't the same as a compost bin. A compost bin/heap is where you can put things such as vegetable peelings, shredded paper and cardboard, garden waste and more - but it's easier for you to look at the online list I mention for dos and don'ts. It requires little maintenance other than turning occasionally, but it can take about two years to produce useable compost. A wormery is usually a tiered system containing worms that munch through your kitchen waste (but not meat or fish) and provide you with liquid fertiliser and worm casts, which will give you useable compost in as little as six months.

People either love or hate wormeries. They do need some attention to get right, as you can overfeed them and you have to be careful not to put too much of one type of food in, such as citrus fruit, bananas and onion skins. You need to keep the pH balanced, and there are stories galore about people who just didn't get on with them. Don't let that put you off. It's perfectly do-able for an eight-year-old and your other boys will love it.

Then there's something called a bokashi bin. I have a compost heap and a bokashi system. The latter involves putting all your kitchen scraps in - cooked or raw meat and fish included - and sprinkling it with bran that contains microscopic bacteria, yeasts and fungi. (The only kitchen waste you can't put in is teabags but I do - I think it's only if you get through tons in a day.) The bran causes the waste to break down quicker. When one bin is full you store it (the lid is airtight so it doesn't smell, although when you open it it smells of pickling) and start on the next one. In two weeks, the full one is ready to be dug straight into vegetable beds or the compost bin (not just dumped on top) where it will break down much quicker. The ongoing cost of bokashi is the bran (about £15 every six months). You also get liquid fertiliser from bokashi, which you dilute (as with the wormery one) - or you can use it neat to clear drains.

You can make do with just a compost heap, otherwise get a wormery or a bokashi system to deal with kitchen waste and use your compost for garden waste. There's a good table online at greengardener.co.uk/compostingtable.htm. I got my bokashi system from there (£59.99 for two bins and 600g of bran) and the service is excellent. It takes you through the pros and cons of each system.

As far as a compost bin goes, you have a choice of either a contained bin or an open one. A contained bin looks a bit like a water butt. I find these a bit limited for space. Once you start composting, it's amazing what you can find to add - shredded paper and cardboard (good to stop your heap getting too sludgy), grass clippings, fallen leaves etc. It fills up fast. I would recommend you just make a compost heap and this link tells you how: gardenersworld.com/how-to/projects/compost-bin.

Otherwise, Wiggly Wigglers (wigglywigglers.co.uk, 01981 500391) specialises in wormeries. The Can-o-Worms kit, which is a wormery plus worms, is £89. I haven't dealt with this company but I know lots of people who have and have been very happy with the result. Green Gardener (greengardener.co.uk, 01603 715096) also sells wormeries. The Junior Wormery (ideal to see how you get on with it) is £39.99 for the wormery and worms. Both companies also do interesting compost bins. Have fun. Your dustbins will be practically empty.

At nearly 900 pages, this is a suitably monumental book about the biggest subject of all: the cosmos. This history of our love affair with the stars was first published in 1993. Now, British historian of astronomy John North has updated it and increased the illustrations by about 200. The scale of the subject is daunting: more than 20,000 scholarly articles are published each year on astronomy, and the roots of our fascination lie as far back as 36,000BC. Archaeologists have found bones from that time carved with moon-shaped marks representing the lunar days of the month. As North says, this was the "first step towards a mathematics of the heavens". From Stonehenge and ancient China, where sunspots were first recorded in 28BC (European astronomers didn't spot them until the 17th century), to today's search for dark matter, Machos and Wimps, this remarkable work brings together the global history, theories, people and technologies of astronomy to tell a story that "has very few intellectual parallels in the whole of human history".

More than 400,000 holidaymakers face severe disruption at the end of the month after staff voted to go on strike at Britain's two busiest airports for charter airlines and low-budget carriers.

Union leaders warned that industrial action at Gatwick and Stansted could spread across the UK with workers at Manchester, Birmingham and Newcastle airports also holding walk-out ballots.

Baggage handlers and check-in staff at Gatwick and Stansted will stage 24-hour strikes on bank holiday Monday, August 25, and on August 29 after rejecting a 3% pay offer. The strike by workers at airport services firm Swissport will affect services by Gatwick-based airlines including Virgin Atlantic, Thomsonfly, Monarch and First Choice, and flights operated by Ryanair and easyJet at Stansted, where they are the biggest customers.

The Unite union said all airlines using Swissport's services would be grounded. "The flights could not operate. If these strikes go ahead it would effectively shut down the airlines' operations," said Steve Turner, Unite's secretary for aviation.

Swissport and airport owner BAA were holding talks with airline bosses last night to gauge whether they can keep flights running with a skeleton workforce. Swissport said it hoped to "minimise disruption to the travelling public" while one airline, Virgin Atlantic, said it had contingency plans in place and expected "business as usual" for its Gatwick flights. Ryanair said it would operate hand-luggage-only flights if the strikes go ahead.

Services to Las Vegas, Lanzarote and Malaga will be among the flights affected on August 25 and 29. Industry experts warned that passengers should at least expect delays, if not cancellations, if last-ditch negotiations fail.

"The airlines and Swissport will attempt to draft in management and where possible use non-unionised workers," said John Strickland, an airline consultant. "There will be a risk of delays and this is worst time of year for it to happen, at the peak of the summer season when flights are their fullest." Swissport said it intended to continue talks with the Unite and GMB unions over averting the strikes.

BAA's much-maligned airports have had an uneventful summer but their vulnerability to operational mishaps was underlined on Thursday, when thousands of passengers at Heathrow's Terminal 3 had to fly without their bags after a computer glitch shut down the baggage handling system. BAA said 3,500 bags were separated from their owners following the software breakdown, which also saw 4,500 passengers ordered to queue outside the terminal after check-in desks were closed. The airport group said airlines had begun reuniting passengers with their bags.

Gatwick and Stansted are the UK's second and third largest airports and will handle a total of more than 200,000 passengers a day over the bank holiday weekend. Holidaymakers will be most affected because both airports are popular with charter and low-budget carriers.

Unite described the 3% pay offer as an insult and has demanded a pay rise of 5% for its members, in the latest pay dispute to focus on the rising rate of inflation. "Our members are already struggling to keep up with rising food and energy costs. This pay offer is an insult to professional, hard-working men and women who have to operate in extremely difficult conditions. Our members have had enough," said Unite's Turner.

A Ryanair spokesman said: "This strike is totally unjustified. Union chiefs should be grateful that they are getting any increase at all at a challenging time for the global economy."

Baggage screeners at Stansted have also voted to go on strike, but the airport said services would not be affected.

BAA is braced for another blow next week, when the Competition Commission is expected to demand the sale of Gatwick and one Scottish airport. The competition watchdog has indicated BAA's monoply over airports in the south-east is bad for airlines and passengers because it encourages the group to hold back plans for runways and under-invest in services.

Music publisher Chrysalis, whose roster includes Portishead and Estelle, warned yesterday that revenue from song royalties would fall this year as it predicted an annual loss across the group.

Chrysalis said net publisher's share (NPS), the royalties it receives after writers, performers and right holders have taken their slice, would be lower in the 13 months to the end of September than for the previous year.

It blamed the "challenging macroeconomic environment" for hampering sales of CDs. The advertising market downturn affected synchronisation revenue, which it gets when music is used in TV programmes, films and advertisements.

Over the 10 months to the end of June, NPS was down 2.9% on last year, reflecting a quiet release schedule in the first half of the year and uncertainty about Chrysalis's future, when it was up for sale. The three months from April to June saw a 12.8% gain, however, thanks to chart hits.

Investec analysts predicted NPS would fall 9% year on year to £11.1m for the 13 months to the end of September. Since rejecting a bid from EMI and ending talks with other potential buyers in April, Chrysalis has identified increasing NPS as a significant way to boost shareholder value.

Chrysalis said its incubator business Echo, which nurtures artists before they sign with big labels, performed below expectations and is under review with other non-publishing assets. It predicted an operating loss for the 13 months that would be at a similar level to the £1.2m it reported for the seven months to the end of March.

This is it. After 13 years in the musty confines of classrooms, watching life go past the windows while the teacher sincerely tries to interest you in the sex life of daffodils, you're free. All right, if you're planning to go to uni it's only for a year: after that your tutors will be clamping you in another set of dusty arms, but that still gives you a year to change and improve the world on your own terms.

And if, like most young people today (57% according to the latest Defra figures), you are fairly worried about climate change, then you may wish to focus your year on the environment. But what is the best way to go about that?

Well, the modern gap-year industry, which is becoming more and more commercialised by the day, caters for everything, so it certainly offers a few ecological opportunities. You can sweep off to combat deforestation in Kenya, or help with wallaby conservation in Australia. You might decide that you want to head to the Arctic to monitor carbon stores in the peat, or whisk yourself to the base of Mount Fuji in Japan to search for endangered butterflies. And these are just a few of the options offered by gap-year organisations under the conservation label: some offer construction work, some want you to work with scientific projects; there are opportunities all over the world that sound equally exotic and exciting, with the additional plus of helping the environment.

Carbon footprint

But before you shout "that's for me, I'm off to save the world", a moment's sober thought is sadly necessary. Leaving aside the high financial cost, many gap-year packages are for just one or two weeks, and, as we all know these days, the carbon cost of flying to the other side of the world is pretty heavy. The emissions from a return flight to Australia equal the emissions of three average cars for a year: you would really have to save a lot of wallabies to compensate for that kind of impact on your carbon footprint. Even more crucially, how much real difference can you make in two weeks anyway?

Kate Simpson runs Ethical Volunteering, a website aimed at helping people to get the most out of their volunteering experience, and she is increasingly concerned about the actual value of some of these projects. "Some of the big agencies are using the environment as a kind of marketing tool and actually what they're selling are essentially holidays." (I noticed that i-to-i, a commercial gap-year organisation now owned by First Choice, advertises projects such as sea turtle conservation in Costa Rica as also being an opportunity to "live the 'beach' lifestyle".)

"The rationale behind a lot of these projects is that you're getting people involved and engaged in the environment. But if they're only going out there for two weeks, I don't see how that can be possible," adds Simpson, who is also concerned about the scientific basis of some of these projects. "Some of them are certainly part of authentic scientific research expeditions, but you need to establish very thoroughly before you go that this is the case. What is the organisation you will be working with? Do they have plans to publish their research?"

And even if they are genuine, how useful will you really be? Last year, Tourism Concern did some research into the overseas voluntary industry, and found some worrying results. Many of the organisations gave skimpy answers to questions about the satisfaction of the community hosting the volunteers: it is obvious in many cases that the happiness of the volunteers takes priority over the happiness of the community they are supposed to be helping. And a third of the volunteers who were questioned thought that their placement had been of greater benefit to them than to the community in which they were placed. One volunteer described feeling that "what I was actually doing wasn't truly benefiting the local community (we did build a playground and they were totally grateful). It was a western ideal and it made me realise that I did it for my own selfish reasons."

But don't despair. There are plenty of ways of having an exciting, wonderful gap year, seeing whole new parts of the world, keeping your carbon footprint low, not going broke, and really making a difference to the environment.

First of all, consider staying closer to home: there are plenty of conservation opportunities in the UK and Europe. Earthwatch, for example, a long-established charity that organises placements with scientific expeditions, has projects off Scotland, while the National Trust and the British Trust of Conservation Volunteers both have green volunteering opportunities. If you're planning to work as well, Phil Murray of Gap Advice suggests do-it.org, a website that will help you choose a volunteering activity that fits in with your working hours. A quick scan shows just how useful this can be: within a few miles of my home in Brighton, for example, I can help to organise the London-Brighton Green Car rally, work with the RSPB, do a few hours at the Peace and Environment centre, sort things out at the Green Library, clean beaches or collect used mobile phones. Or you could get involved in some of the energetic environmental campaigns taking part around the country: groups such as Friends of the Earth, Plane Stupid, Rising Tide, the Climate Camp and Greenpeace are always looking for volunteers for fundraising, newsletter-writing, or non-violent direct action, whichever appeals to you most.

European horizons

If you were at least hoping to leave the country, there is a large landmass usually referred to as Europe, which has a reputation for a fair amount of diversity and complexity. Wwoof (World Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms) has been going for over 20 years: it's basically a network where organic farmers looking for help post messages. The possibilities are unbelievable as Wwoof, which started up in England, now stretches around the world. If you want to go somewhere a train-ride away, you could be gathering hazelnuts in Piedmont, Italy, herding goats in the Austrian Tyrol or building a straw-bale house in Asturias, Spain: it's actually quite hard to look through the websites without making immediate plans to set off. Wwoof is an astonishing key to unique experiences.

Finally, no one in the world would say you're forbidden from travelling long distances. Sure, flying to South America may be a huge chunk of carbon emissions, but everyone deserves the opportunity to see the other side of the world at least once in their life. Just try to be wise with it. Is it really worth going just for two weeks? When you get there must you plane-hop from country to country? Perhaps the best thing would be to consider one of the long-term placements such as those offered by Lattitude. They might send you to Ecuador to work in an ecotourism centre in the cloud forests for six months, or to Brazil for five months to help to build an eco-village.

"The most important thing," says Dr Simpson, "is to ask questions, find out who you're travelling with and think it all through very carefully. Volunteering is a long and great tradition: for hundreds and thousands of young people, it's a brilliant experience. There are always going to be downsides: you just have to try to nudge it all in the right direction."

Fears that the UK economy is heading into recession sent sterling tumbling against the dollar for the eleventh day in a row yesterday - its longest losing streak since the break-up of the Bretton Woods fixed exchange system in 1971.

The pound fell to its lowest level against the US currency in almost two years on expectations that the Bank of England will be forced to cut the cost of borrowing to boost growth. A pick-up in US industrial production also helped a resurgent dollar and pushed down the price of oil and gold on global commodity markets.

The pound closed at $1.85 on the foreign exchanges. It is down 6.5% since July, a move that will make it more expensive for British holidaymakers to visit the United States but will make UK exports cheaper to the world's biggest market.

Michael Saunders at Citigroup said: "Sterling remains vulnerable, especially against the US dollar. The pound averaged $1.55/£ over 1993-2002 and it would not be a surprise to see a return to those levels in the next 12-18 months."

Tim Clayton, chief strategist at currency consultancy Investica, said: "The US was the first economy to hit trouble. Now people are realising that the UK has the same problems, if not more so, as the US."

Speculation about a cut in the cost of borrowing has intensified after the governor of the Bank of England, Mervyn King delivered a bleak assessment of the British economy on Wednesday. The Bank has kept interest rates at 5% since April, as inflation has risen to 4.4% - more than double its 2% target - but Threadneedle Street believes growth in the economy will grind to a halt over the coming year.

King said that there were "bound" to be one or two quarters of falling output as the UK felt the full force of rising commodity prices and the year-long credit crunch, with living standards under severe pressure. The Bank believed that the collapse in housing starts to a postwar low could reduce growth by between a quarter and half a percentage point.

"Increases in food and energy bills will intensify the squeeze on real take-home pay which, for many households, is unlikely to grow this year," King said at a press conference for the Bank's quarterly inflation report. "These are circumstances in which consumer spending and house prices are likely to weaken together."

Oil dropped to $112 a barrel yesterday, continuing its slide from a record of $147 a month ago. A rising dollar typically pushes oil lower as investors who buy crude and other commodities as hedges against inflation start dumping their positions to cut their losses.

US crude fell $2.67 to $112.34 after dipping to $111.34 at one stage, the lowest price since May 2. London Brent lost $2.52 to $111.16. Speculation that the global economic slowdown will diminish demand, and that the Russia-Georgia conflict will not interrupt deliveries put crude under downward pressure yesterday.
